data.title: My Wheelhouse
data.meta_description: Posts about Isle Royale written by TedG
data.text:
We’ve been mapping the bottom of Lake Superior at Isle Royale National Park (Michigan) over the past week. This is a scene from my seat this past Sunday. This is the Rock Harbor Light. It is no longer active as … Continue reading →

I have written about Isle Royale in various forms, but I realized I have never really introduced readers to the island itself, or at least not very well. So I’d like you to meet the island. Isle Royale is a … Continue reading →

Isn’t that what people call those mornings when the sky is crystal clear and deep blue? A “bluebird morning”? That’s what today is. Even though it’s about 4 degrees Fahrenheit and a bit windy–a.k.a. cold. Despite the name of the … Continue reading →

For those who are interested in following other wolf-moose research, Ky and Lisa Koitzsch work both in Yellowstone National Park and, currently, in Isle Royale National Park. They are posting photos and stories from their work in both places on … Continue reading →

The Isle Royale wolf-moose study is the longest-running predator-prey research program in the country (the world?), at 56 years. Every year, the research team goes to the island (which is closed to visitation from October to April) and conducts their … Continue reading →

4/22- Our friends at Isle Royale National Park report that the U.S. Coast Guard icebreaker, Katmai Bay, assisted the park’s LCM (landing craft) through the ice that is clogging the Portage Lake channel between the park headquarters in Houghton, Michigan, … Continue reading →

More snow overnight – 7 inches here at home. Schools closed again. Robins looking frustrated. The word from staff at Isle Royale National Park (northwestern Lake Superior) last week was that the first round of park staff were heading to … Continue reading →

On my way to work one bright March morning, I heard a story on National Public Radio about a team of scientists who were roaming the river bottom forests of Louisiana in search of a ghost. They played a recording … Continue reading →

When my brother and his girlfriend announced their engagement, my aunt thought they were too young to be married. They were both in their early 20s at the time and both still in college. Thus, my aunt seemed to think, … Continue reading →
